comments.author: wtc@google.com
comments.text:
RNG_SystemInfoForRNG calls RNG_FileUpdate to read several files.
Some of them, such as "/etc/passwd", may contain sensitive info.

So RNG_FileUpdate should zero its stack buffer before returning:
http://bonsai.mozilla.org/cvsblame.cgi?file=mozilla/security/nss/lib/freebl/unix_rand.c&rev=1.39&mark=990,996#990
comments.raw_text:
RNG_SystemInfoForRNG calls RNG_FileUpdate to read several files.
Some of them, such as "/etc/passwd", may contain sensitive info.

So RNG_FileUpdate should zero its stack buffer before returning:
http://bonsai.mozilla.org/cvsblame.cgi?file=mozilla/security/nss/lib/freebl/unix_rand.c&rev=1.39&mark=990,996#990
comments.creator: wtc@google.com

comments.text:
Created attachment 518815
Patch by Alpha Lam of Google
comments.creator: wtc@google.com
comments.author: wtc@google.com
wtc@google.com
comments.text:
The data in "/etc/passwd" is ultimately passed to RNG_RandomUpdate
in drbg.c.  RNG_RandomUpdate may store it in globalrng->additionalDataCache.

It would be nice to zero globalrng->additionalDataCache whenever
we reset globalrng->additionalAvail to 0.  (Search for
"->additionalAvail = " in drbg.c.)
comments.raw_text:
The data in "/etc/passwd" is ultimately passed to RNG_RandomUpdate
in drbg.c.  RNG_RandomUpdate may store it in globalrng->additionalDataCache.

It would be nice to zero globalrng->additionalDataCache whenever
we reset globalrng->additionalAvail to 0.  (Search for
"->additionalAvail = " in drbg.c.)
comments.creator: wtc@google.com

comments.author: nelson@bolyard.me
comments.creator: nelson@bolyard.me
comments.raw_text:
/etc/passwd is a PUBLIC file.  There is no need to wipe it from memory.
Any attacker could just open and read the file himself.
comments.text:
/etc/passwd is a PUBLIC file.  There is no need to wipe it from memory.
Any attacker could just open and read the file himself.
